content.description: Awesome crimp problem with a deadpoint crux. Start matched in a slot at head height and head straight up through a handful of small crimps. The crux revolves around a precise move to a mailbox slot that is definitely harder the shorter you are. From there, trend left on jugs to another slippery mantle. There is potential for a lower start.
content.location: Just to the right of Hustle Bones. Just like that problem, this one is also covered in a waterfall in the spring.

content.description: An excellent problem on super cool holds. Start as for Green Room, but after the big cross to the sloper, angle right up the sloping rail. Once at a large shelf, get those feet up, grab the sweet wave feature and rock over. Top out as for Green Room

Start low on large positive crimps and a sideways foot out to your right. Move up and left through a series of good crimps and crappy feet until your hands are high enough to get a foot onto the face. Rock over to a super hard to see slot crimp and then up to a huge jug. Top out with an easy but water polished mantle.
content.location: On the second tier of boulders to the left of the Green Room. This problem takes the left line up the rippled wave feature. Note: this and it's neighbor are under a waterfall for most of the spring, so expect to need to do a little bit of clean up if it's been wet recently

content.description: It's probably worth coming to Abbey Pond just to do this problem. Start matched on the crimp rail and make a big move up left to a sloping crimp. Throw a heel up, make a big cross, and then bust progressively harder moves up the arete, culminating in either a big move to a jug or a delicate rock over onto the face. The top out is easy but tends to get a little dirty, so it might be worth cleaning it off before you send.
content.location: This climb takes the right side of the prominent wavelike feature on the second tier of boulders. This is right above the top out for Iron Horse and Tin Pony.

content.description: Home to some of the best rock at Abbey Pond.Â
